dict.string: What is the person and number is the verb ‘erat’?
Apollo Acrisio dixit: ‘filia te necabit (will kill)’
Which word is the pronoun in this sentence?
Acrisios filiam suam in cista (chest) posuit
‘posuit’ - what is the first person singular of the present tense of this verb?
What case is insulam and why?

rex insulae Danaen ducere cupiebat
(king)  (Danae acc) (to marry)
Which English word derives from the Latin word ‘iratus’?
Which of these Latin sentences is the correct translation?
Which of these Latin sentences is the correct translation?
olim Hector et Paris in Sparta manebant
What is the Latin subject of the verb manebant?
What is Latin object of regebat?
ubi Paris Helenam vidit, magnopere amabat
What is the adverb in this sentence?
itaque Paris Helenam ad Troiam (Troy) ducere cupiebat
What case is Troiam and why?
ad forces Troi-am into the accusative case
What is the first person singular, present tense of cepit?
What is the present tense equivalent of erat?
Which of these is an English derivation of iratus?
What is the correct Latin translation of woman here?
woman has to be accusative singular as object of the verb
What is the correct Latin translation of this sentence?
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
ubi Paris Helenam cepit, Menelaus erat iratus
What is the adjective in this sentence?
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
What case is Agamemnonem and why?
accusative - ad forces it into this case
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
Agamemnon ad regiam (palace) suam amicos vocavit
Put vocavit in the present tense, keeping person and number

vocavit = (he) called
voc-at = (he) calls
present tense, first conjugation
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
What is the present tense equivalent of erant?
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
What is the Latin subject of the verb constituerunt?
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
What part of the verb capio is capere?
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
nautae Graeci in portu (harbour) diu manebant
What gender is the word Graeci?
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
Artemis dea nautis ventos non dedit
What is the first person singular present tense of dedit?
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
What is the correct translation of ‘remain’?
The Greeks sail to Troy to win back Helen
What is the correct Latin translation of this sentence?
ubi Graeci ad Troiam venerunt, e navibus (ships) discesserunt
What is the first person singular present tense of discesserunt?
What case is ora and why?
contra Troianos in saevis proeliis pugnabant
Put pugnabant into the present tense, keeping person and number
What is the Latin object of ceperunt?
What is the Latin subject of the verb erant?
<font color="#F5C343">Graeci</font> is a Latin word and nominative plural here
What is the adverb in this sentence?
What is the imperative in this sentence?
imperative is a verb part used when giving an order
Agamemnon multa et irata verba dixit
What gender is the word verba?
What is the correct translation of fear in this sentence?
What is the correct translation of this sentence?

viri (nom plu)
gladios (acc plu)
habent (have, present, they)
The Anger of Achilles Part One
quod Troiani eos (them) saepe superabant, Graeci erant miseri
Which word does miseri agree with?
The Anger of Achilles Part One
post (after) unum proelium, Agamemnon feminam Troianam cepit
What is the first person singular present tense of cepit?
<font color="#F5C343">capio</font> is the root word of <font color="#F5C343">cepit</font>
The Anger of Achilles Part One
The Anger of Achilles Part One
The Anger of Achilles Part One
pater (father) feminae erat sacerdos (priest) dei Apollonis (Apollo)
Put <font color="#F5C343">dei</font> into the plural in the same case.
The Anger of Achilles Part One
Apollo igitur in Graecos sagittas mittebat
What case is sagittas and why?
The Anger of Achilles Part One
Agamemnon non fuit laetus quod feminam amabat
Put <font color="#F5C343">fuit</font> into the present tense, keeping person and number.

fuit (he) was
est (he) is
third person singular
The Anger of Achilles Part One
sed tandem patri (father - dative) feminam statim dedit
What type of word is statim?
The Anger of Achilles Part One
The priest shouted: ‘Give back the slave girl!’
What is the correct translation of slave girl here?
The Anger of Achilles Part One
We do not have a queen.
What is the correct Latin translation of this sentence?

non (not)
habe-mus (we have)
regin-am (acc sing as object of habemus)
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
ubi viri puellam ceperunt, Achilles erat magnopere iratus
What type of word is ubi?
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
Achilles showed his anger to (dative) the Greeks
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
dum (while) Graeci audiebant, Achilles verba saeva clamavit
What word does saeva agree with in this sentence?
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
‘quod feminam meam cepisti, Agamemnon, non iam pugno’
Put <font color="#F5C343">cepisti</font> in the present tense, keeping person and number.

cepisti (2nd person sing perfect)
capis (2nd person singular present)
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
itaque Achilles e bello viros suos duxit.
What case is <font color="#F5C343">bello</font> and why?
e forces bell-o into the ablative case
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
Achilles cum viris suis in tabernaculo (tent) manebat
Which word is the adjective in this sentence?
agrees with <font color="#F5C343">viris</font> and is a possessive adjective (his)
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
Agamemnon tamen timebat; Achilles erat optimus (best) Graecorum
timebat - was afraid. How would you say ‘is afraid’?
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
How would you translate 'the friend' here?
amic-um has to be accusative sing, object of frightens
The Anger of Achilles Part Two
What is the correct Latin translation of this sentence?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
<font color="#F5C343">Achilles in bello contra Troianos pugnare non iam cupiebat</font>
What case is <font color="#F5C343">bello</font> and why?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
<font color="#F5C343">Graeci circum muros Troiae</font> (Troy) <font color="#F5C343">fortiter pugnabant</font>
What case and number is <font color="#F5C343">Troiae</font>?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
<font color="#F5C343">sed Troiani eos</font> (them) <font color="#F5C343">in multis proeliis superabant</font>
Which word is the adjective in this sentence?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
<font color="#F5C343">Patroclus, amicus Achillis</font> (Achilles), <font color="#F5C343">ubi hoc</font> (this) <font color="#F5C343">vidit, non erat laetus</font>
What is the present tense equivalent of <font color="#F5C343">vidit</font>?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
What is the first person singular present tense of <font color="#F5C343">cucurrit</font>?
<font color="#F5C343">cucurri</font> is the perfect of <font color="#F5C343">curro</font>
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
‘da mihi (to me) scutum tuum et gladium’
What part of the verb <font color="#F5C343">do</font> is <font color="#F5C343">da</font>?
imperative = used when giving an order
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
What gender is the word <font color="#F5C343">proelium</font>?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
Achilles consilium (plan) non amavit sed tandem consentit (agreed)
What is the Latin object of the verb amavit?
Achilles didn’t like the plan (object of the verb)
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
The Anger of Achilles: Part Three
The friends hurry to the place.
What is the correct Latin translation of this sentence?

amici (nom plu)
locum (acc sing after ad)
festinant (they hurry)
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
Achilles in bello contra Troianos adhuc (still) non pugnabat
What case is Troianos and why?
preposition contra forces Troian-os into the accusative case
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
Patroclus eum (him) rogavit: ‘mitte me in proelium!’
What is the imperative in this sentence?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
Achilles Patroclo gladium suum et scutum dedit.
What case is Patroclo and why?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
What type of word is fortiter?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
Hector, filius Priami (of Priam), fuit optimus (best) Troianorum
What is the first person singular present tense of fuit?
root word of <font color="#F5C343">fuit</font> is <font color="#F5C343">sum</font> = I am
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
ubi Hector Patroclum vidit, eum (him) Achillem esse credebat (he believed)
What is the present tense equivalent of vidit?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
Hector ad Patroclum festinavit et statim necavit
What is the subject of the verb necavit?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
Graeci corpus (body) Patrocli ad Achillem portaverunt
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
The Anger of Achilles: Part Four
Which is the correct Latin translation of this sentence?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
Achilles de morte (death) Patrocli mox audivit
Which word is the preposition in this sentence?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
Achilles miser erat et diu flebat (cried)
What type of word is diu?
<font color="#F5C343">diu</font> = for a long time = time adverb
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
Achilles, quod erat iratus, iterum pugnare constituit
What part of the verb pugno is pugnare?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
gladium et scutum cepit et e tabernaculo (tent) discessit
What is the first person singular present tense of discessit?
root word of <font color="#F5C343">discessit</font> is <font color="#F5C343">discedo</font>
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
Achilles Hectorem (Hector - acc) invenire (to find) magnopere cupiebat
What is the subject of cupiebat?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
Hector erat validus et multos viros necabat
What gender is the adjective <font color="#F5C343">validus</font> in this sentence?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
Achilles Hectorem necavit et e proelio corpus (body) portavit
What case is proelio and why?
preposition <font color="#F5C343">e</font> takes the ablative case
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
Achilles saevus circum muros oppidi Hectorem traxit (dragged)
What gender is the noun <font color="#F5C343">oppidi</font>?
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
The Anger of Achilles: Part Five
What is the correct Latin translation of this sentence?
sic Troiani Graecos in bello superabant
What is the Latin subject of superabant?
Graeci, quod erant miseri, e Troia navigare cupiebant
What is the conjunction in this sentence?
Put habuit in the present tense, keeping person and number
What is the Latin object of aedificare?
equ-um acc sing and object of aedificare
Graeci equum in ora prope Troiam posuerunt
What is the first person singular present tense of posuerunt?
Graeci discesserunt et ad insulam vicinam (nearby) navigaverunt
What case is insulam and why?
Put spectabant into the present tense, keeping person and number
What is the Latin object of dederunt?
We don’t like the Greeks’ gifts
What is the correct Latin translation of this sentence?
Troiani, ubi in ora equum viderunt, perterriti steterunt
What is the first person singular present tense of steterunt?
unus vir, Laocoon, dixit: ‘Graecos timeo quamquam (although) donum dederunt’
What tense is the verb dederunt?
sed Troiani responderunt: ‘equus est deae donum’
What gender is the word equus?
What part of the verb duco is ducite?
imperative used when giving an order
sed in equo erant multi Graeci viri
What type of word is multi?
Troiani multum vinum biberunt (drank) et multum cibum consumpserunt
What is the Latin subject of consumpserunt?
The Trojans (in Latin, Troian-i) did the eating
dum (while) Troiani dormiebant, Graeci ex equo venerunt
What case is equo and why?
Graeci per vias cucurrerunt et multos Troianos necaverunt
What type of word is per?
horses, object of verb = equ-os, acc plu
What is the correct Latin translation of this sentence?
